As the name suggests regression stands for prediction of continuous numerical value and linear stands for use of linear model. Linear model means output/prediction of the model is a linear combination of features. Mathematical representation given here shall be elaborated in detail.

In this section, we shall start with discussing the intuition using a 2 dimensional example and then present the generic representation.

As the name suggests regression stands for prediction of continuous numerical value and linear stands for use of linear model. Linear model means output/prediction of the model is a linear combination of features. Mathematical representation given here shall be elaborated in detail.

In this section, we shall start with discussing the intuition using a 2 dimensional example and then present the generic representation.

Consider the data points indicated in figure 1. The x coordinate is the value of feature or dependent variable. This is a single feature example, that is the input has only one feature or parameter or variable to define itself. The value on y coordinate is the value of output or dependent variable.

We can see that there can be many lines fitting to this set of points as indicated in figure 2. However, we have to find the best line as indicated in figure 3. The best line shall be decided based on a function also known as loss function which we shall discuss subsequently.

This best fit line shown as line of regression in figure 3 is used for prediction on unseen data, that is query point. And this best fit line is our model. Here we can see that our model is a line whose equation is of the form of equation of a line as indicated on the slide. This is an example shown in 2 dimensions with single feature for visualization.

Figure 4 is an example of linear regression shown in 3 dimensions for data with 2 features. Here, X and Y axes represent features of data points and zed is the output. This is the normal mathematical terminology used for 3 dimensional representation.

Figure 5 is same as figure 4. Only the variable and output notations are changed to suit machine learning convention for this learning module.

We can observe that the model here is a plane rather than a line. Similarly, as we move in higher dimensions, we will get hyper planes as model. Hyper plane is the generic name used for linear combination of features in machine learning or dependent variables in conventional mathematics. A model for 4 feature data points which is also a hyper plane in 5 dimensions is represented as equation A. In this equation, x 1 , x 2 , x 3 , x 4 are features; y is dependent variable; w 1 , w 2 , w 3 , w 4 are weights; and b is bias.

In general a hyper plane for n featured data can be represented as equation B, where sigma i = 1 to n represents summation of n terms.

Linear Regression is about finding the best fit hyper plane for the given data. Let us consider a data set with n data points and d features or dimensions. This data will be represented in matrix form as shown here.

The feature number j of data point number i is represented as x i j, while dependent variable number i is represented as y i. Let us discuss this notation in detail. Each row in X & Y is a data point. While rows in X represent features or dimensions or independent variable of data point, rows in Y represent the value of dependent variable. Thus x 1 1, x 1 2, x 1 3 to x 1 d represent values of features of 1st data point, and y 1 represents value of dependent variable of 1st data point. In general, x i 1, x i 2, x i 3 to x i d represent values of features of data point number i, and y i represents value of dependent variable of data point number i.

Our aim is to find a hyper plane which fits the data set represented by X and Y shown earlier. This hyper plane can be represented as equation 1.

where x i is the features of data point number i, y i is dependent variable of data point number i, w is the weight vector and b is bias.

This equation can be expanded as expand 1.

In matrix form it can be represented as X W transpose plus b equal to Y. Here W is the vector representing weights, b is bias, X and Y are the data set as shown earlier. Vector W is represented as shown on the slide.

The task in linear regression is to find this W and b.

Ideally with W & b, equation 1 should be satisfied by all the data points (like a system of linear equations with 1 solution). However, this does not happen. Hence, the task in linear regression is to find the best fit hyper plane with the help of loss function. Loss function will be discussed in a while.

As equation 1 is not satisfied by all the data points, so the equation of hyper plane is modified as equation 2, where this symbol is read as y i hat, and is the predicted value of dependent variable obtained by substituting the value of x i in equation 2.

We can see that for a given data set, the predicted value of dependent variable y i hat is different from actual value of dependent variable y i. This difference is known as error and is represented as equation 3, where e i is the error value for data point number i.

Refer figure 6 for depiction of error.

A while ago we discussed about finding the best fit hyper plane. This best fit is obtained by reducing the error values of all the data points. In case of linear regression, best fit is obtained by reducing the mean squared error represented as equation 4, where L is referred as loss.

Equation 4 is known as Loss function or Cost function. Loss refers to the total error while fitting a hyper plane, and the best fit hyper plane is the one for which this loss is minimum. This loss in linear regression is called mean squared error or M S E. M S E was decided as loss function for linear regression based on empirical results.

In general for any machine learning model we have a loss function which need not be M S E. We will discuss other loss functions as and when required.

Thus our aim is to find W and b such that loss defined by equation 4 is minimum.

Mathematical formulation for linear regression can be represented as equation 5. In this equation W star and b star are best values for weights and bias. Arg min stands for finding such W and b which minimizes the loss function.

Expanding equation 4 by substituting y i hat from equation 2, we get expand 4.

As soon as we come across minimizing something in mathematics, our attention is drawn towards minima. We have to find the minima of L and the corresponding values of weights and bias. In order to find the value of minima, we need to perform partial differentiation of L with respect to all the weights and bias. This brings us to a very important concept which is omni present in machine learning. The concept of gradient descent. Let us discuss it with the help of L and single weight w.

Figure 6 shows a graph between L and w. The minima of L is achieved in 6 iterations. Let w is initialized randomly at point 1. To move towards point 6 it takes the first step and updates itself using equation 6. In 4 following steps it reaches minima. In equation 6, eta is learning rate which has a small value , t is the iteration step or number. Del L by del w at step t minus 1 is calculated by substituting the value of w at time step t minus 1 in del L by del w.

With this general understanding of gradient descent, we shall proceed towards applying it to linear regression.

When we apply gradient descent to our loss function, we get equation 7 and equation 8 as general update equation for weights and bias respectively. In equation 7, w i represents weight number i and t represents iteration number.

Now, our task is to find del L by del w i and del L by del b which will be obtained by partial differentiation of L in equation 4. Thus we get equation 9 and 10 as partial derivatives of L with respect to weights and bias respectively.

After every iteration that is update of weights and bias, loss is calculated and iterations are stopped as soon as change in loss becomes negligible. Iteration stop criteria is represented by equation 11.

Now, we shall discuss a very important concept in the whole of machine learning with the perspective of linear regression. We are going to discuss bias and variance. We train or fit a model on train data set and evaluate the results on test data set. If error is high for both train and test data set that is model is not giving good results for both train and test datasets, the model is said to have high bias or model is under fitting. If error is low on train data set and is high on test data set, the model is said to have high variance or model is over fitting. This is depicted in figure 8. It may be noted that as model complexity increases, the model tries hard to fit to data and results in high variance or over fitting. As the model complexity is low, the model does not fit well to all the data points and thus is under fitting. In the whole of machine learning, we try to find the best trade-off between bias and variance. The best trade-off is obtained by hyper parameter tuning. We will learn about hyper parameter in while.

We have seen the loss function for linear regression as equation 4 which is reproduced here. As the model complexity is increased the model has tendency to over fit. We shall learn about model complexity as we progress in the learning module.

In order to avoid over fitting, we add a regularization term to mean square error and rewrite the loss function as equation 12. In the regularization term, lambda is coefficient of regularization or regularization constant which is a hyper parameter. This regularization is known as L 2 regularization. There are other forms of regularization also. λ is divided by 2 n to maintain consistency in loss function.

We know that λ is a hyper parameter. Let us understand the term hyper parameter. The weights and bias are parameters which are learnt during the model training. However hyper parameters are not learnt during training and are found by hit and trial method. We check different values of a hyper parameter and choose the one which gives best result. Today this task of hit and trial is done by machine learning software packages. The process of finding the best value for a hyper parameter is known as hyper parameter tuning.

Now, the value of λ has a great significance in regularization. If lambda value is too high, model will be simple with the risk of under fitting. The model won't learn enough about the training data to make useful predictions. If lambda value is too low, model will be more complex with the risk of over fitting. The model will learn too much about the particularities of the training data, and won't be able to generalize to new data. The ideal value of lambda produces a model that generalizes well to new and previously unseen data. That ideal value of lambda is data-dependent, so you will need to do some tuning.

This brings us to the end of mathematics for linear regression.

Now we will see the code implementation of Linear Regression. Code files in dot i p y n b and dot p y formats can be downloaded from resources.

So, where do we write the codes? We shall write codes in a web based I D E or Integrated Development Environment. An I D E is software for building applications that combines common developer tools into a single G U I or Graphical User Interface. Simply put an I D E is software where an user can write codes and compile or run them. We shall be using Google Colaboratory or colab as an I D E for writing and running our codes. Colab requires an user to have a Google account to be able to use it. There are lots of advantages of Colab. Once signed in, the file generated in coalab with extension dot i p y n b gets saved in google drive. Colab provides G P U or Graphical Processing unit for computation which makes it very fast. As Colab is web based or cloud based, it can be accessed from anywhere by any device capable of running a web browser and having internet. It comes with 12.5 GB of usable RAM in its free version. No initial installation is required. Many popular packages come pre-installed, example scikit learn, tensorflow.

We shall now start using Colab. Go to any browser, sign in to your Google account, and search for Google Colaboratory in any search engine preferably Google. You will get a search result as shown here. Click on the first link. You will get a screen like this. If you are using it for the first time you will not get many recent files. Click on this link. You will get a screen like this. Now go to file tab on the top left and click on new notebook option. You will get a screen like this. You can change the name of this notebook from here.

As we move the cursor on a code cell, an option to add another code cell or text cell appears above and below the existing code cell. This can be seen in these screenshots. Now we are all set to write codes. We shall be using a data set in the form of a c s v file. This data set is called Machining and can be downloaded from resources. Let us visualize this data set. To visualize this data set, we shall use pandas library which is a very powerful library for handling data frames. We import pandas using this code snippet. Also we shall upload the Machining data set in the runtime. Now, we shall read the data set using this code snippet. Here, we read the data set as a data frame and save it in a variable named Machining. We can see the data frame by just typing Machining and running it in a code cell as shown here. We can see all the column names of the data frame. The left most column is numbering of rows or data points also known as index. We see that there are 506 rows and 9 columns. This is the shape of data frame. The shape of data frame can also be seen by running this code snippet. The output tuple shows number of rows as first entry and number of columns as second entry.

The Machining data set that we visualized in the last slide is from the domain of mechanical or production engineering. It tries to find out relation between surface finish and various machining parameters. The data set consists of 9 columns. Out of these nine columns, the column named Finish is output or dependent variable. Other columns are parameters or features or independent variables. The description of columns are given on this slide.

We shall now split the data set into features and output using the code snippet shown on the slide. The features and output are saved into variables named X and y respectively.

In any machine learning task, we need data to train model and data to test model. These are generally called train and test data and contain different sets of data points. We shall split the Machine data set to get train and test data sets. The split will be done such that 25% of data is assigned to test data set and 75% is used as train data. We shall use a very popular package called scikit learn or s k learn to do the desired splitting. Code snippet is as shown on the slide. We can see that first train test split module of s k learn is imported from s k learn dot model underscore selection. Test size is set to 0.25 which indicates that 25% of the total data shall be used as test data. Random state is a parameter which can be ignored. However, it is fixed so that the results are same every time the code is run. Learners are encouraged to read the documentation of s k learn train test split and other codes used in this learning module. This is required so that learners become comfortable at using new libraries when required.

Now, we shall perform data preprocessing. Please remember that train test split should be done before pre-processing so that completely untouched and unseen data is available for testing the model. This will become more clear as we progress through this module.

We shall now do imputation of missing data. The strategy shall be median. Code snippet is as shown on the slide. Simple imputer is defined and called as imputer or saved as an instance named imputer. The imputer is fit on train data. Fitting means imputer is adjusted on train data, that is median used for imputation is calculated using train data. Then the train data is transformed using imputer, that is imputation is performed on train data. Thus the X underscore train data available now is free from missing values.

We shall now perform scaling of data. The strategy used shall be standard scaling. Code snippet is as shown on the slide. Standard scaler is defined and called as scaler. The scaler is fit on train data, that is mean and standard deviation are calculated using train data. Then the train data is transformed using scaler, that is scaling is performed on train data. Thus the X underscore train data available now is free from missing values and is scaled.

All the columns of the Machining data set are numerical and there are no categorical columns. Hence, one hot encoding is not required.

With this, data pre-processing phase is over.

Now we shall train a linear regression model. To perform linear regression first we import Linear Regression module from s k learn dot linear underscore model. We define a Linear Regression model and call it as regressor. Then we fit the regressor on X underscore train and y underscore train. Thus our model gets trained. Code snippet for this training is shown on the slide.

Our model is now ready for prediction. Prediction shall be made on test data or X underscore test. Before doing the prediction, the test data shall undergo imputation and scaling. For these transformation, already fit imputer and scaler shall be used. Then prediction shall be done using trained model named regressor. Please note that test data is totally unseen data, that is the test data is not used for training. The already defined or fit imputer and scaler are used for transforming test data to make it ready for prediction.
